title: Tele-calling and Sales Communication
introduction: Tele-calling is a sales technique where representatives contact potential or existing customers via telephone to generate leads, make sales, and provide customer service. This module covers definitions, approaches, frameworks, and best practices for tele-calling, along with the key skills needed for success.

content.value: Tele-calling is selling a company's product or service over the telephone. It includes aspects of telemarketing, telesales, and even direct sales when combined with personal interactions.
Example: A tele-caller of a bank contacting customers about a new credit card offer.
Telemarketing
Telemarketing will call the customer to create an interest in the product or services with detailed information.
Telemarketing helps tele-callers by identifying promising leads for proper sales.
Example: A bank Telemarketing person calls customers to inform them of the new credit card with benefits and gather the interest of the customer.
Telesales
Telesales focuses on making sales to customers over the phone.
Sales representatives engage in one-on-one conversations with potential buyers, presenting products or services and closing deals.
Example: Telesales Person of the bank calls the interested customer and sells the new credit card.
Direct Sales

items: Calling the existing customer and target customer for purchasing another product
Direct sales are sales that occur between a brand and the end-user without a middleman or distributor.

content.value: Example: A sales person or field officer of a bank will reach the customer in person in their place or at the bank and sell the credit card.

content.value: It is a problem or frustration a customer experiences when interacting with a product or service.
Types of Customer Pain Points

items: Financial pain points (e.g., high cost, hidden fees)
Process pain points (e.g., long wait times, complicated processes)
Support pain points (e.g., poor customer service)

content.value: How to Address Customer Pain Points

items: Start the conversation by showing genuine curiosity in the other person. Begin with small talk to look for shared interests or common ground.
Asking open-ended questions encourages deeper conversations and demonstrates that you’re actively listening. You’ll quickly build mutual trust and lay the foundation for a strong relationship.
Listening actively to customers to find the type of point.
Providing tailored solutions by educating customers about product benefits that will provide the best solution to their pain points

content.value: The framework in sales refers to a structured approach or methodology that sales professionals use to guide their sales process, including identifying potential customers, qualifying leads, presenting solutions, handling objections, and closing deals
AIDA Model: Attention, Interest, Desire, and Action for structuring sales pitches.
Example: Selling a new mobile phone to a customer

items: Attention – Introducing the new XYZ Phone with a stunning camera and long battery life! (Grab interest with a bold statement)
Interest – It has a 108MP camera, a 2-day battery, and a super-fast processor—perfect for work and play! (Highlight key features)
Desire – Imagine capturing pro-level photos, never worrying about battery life, and enjoying ultra-smooth gaming. (Make them feel the need)
Action – Order now and get a 20% discount + free wireless earbuds! Limited stock available! (Create urgency and a call to action)

content.value: SPIN Selling: Situation, Problem, Implication, and Need-Payoff questioning technique.
Example: Selling a new credit card to the customer.

items: Situation: Do you frequently travel or shop online? (Understanding the customer's lifestyle)
Problem: Do you ever face high transaction fees or struggle with rewards on your current card? (Identifying their pain points)
Implication: If you’re not earning cashback or travel points, you’re losing money on every purchase. (Highlighting the downside of not switching)
Need-Payoff: Our XYZ Credit Card gives 5% cashback on shopping and free airport lounge access—wouldn’t that save you money and improve your experience? (Presenting your card as the solution)

content.value: BANT Framework: Budget, Authority, Need, and Timing for lead qualification.
Example: Selling a business loan

items: Budget – How much funding are you looking for? (Checking affordability)
Authority – Are you the one making the financial decisions for your company? (Ensuring you're speaking to the right person)
Need – Are you facing cash flow issues or planning business expansion? (Understanding their pain point)
Timeline – Are you looking for funds immediately, or planning for the next quarter? (Knowing when they will buy)

content.value: FAB Framework: Feature, Advantage, and Benefits.
Example: Selling a water purifier.

items: Feature – This purifier has a 7-stage filtration system. (What it has)
Advantage – It removes 99.9% of bacteria and heavy metals from water. (Why it’s better)
Benefit – Your family gets pure, safe drinking water, reducing health risks. (How it helps)

They need to understand the customer’s language and explain in easily understandable terms.
